<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
C-SUITE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/18/fortune-500-rankings-include-37-female-ceos?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Fortune 500: Record Highs, Disappointing Lows
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="female CEOs" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMDA3L2ZvcnR1bmVfNTAwLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Fortune 500 list is a bit like prom: Walmart’s been queen eight-years running, and you can <em>pretty</em> much guess who else is joining onstage. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But there’s another group worth keeping tabs on—companies with female CEOs, which last year <a href="https://fortune.com/2020/05/18/women-ceos-fortune-500-2020/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jumped 12%</a> to...37. That means just 7.4% of Fortune 500 companies have a female CEO. Of those...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Only three in the Global 500 are women of color (Gap’s Sonia Syngal, AMD’s Lisa Su, Yum China’s Joey Wat); none are black or Latina.  </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Seven lead a Fortune 100 company. More head smaller companies at the bottom of the rankings. </span></li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Things are improving...slowly</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But the lack of representation bleeds into other senior leadership positions, like board rooms.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>According to Deloitte’s Women in the Boardroom, 18% of North American board seats in 2018 were </span><span><a href="https://hbr.org/2020/02/gender-parity-in-the-boardroom-wont-happen-on-its-own?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">held by women</a></span><span>, while 4.5% of chairs were.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Last year, California became the first state to set a </span><span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/17/us/california-boardroom-gender-quota.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">minimum requirement</a></span><span> for female board members at publicly held companies.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">One trend to watch:</strong> Research into the “<a href="https://freakonomics.com/podcast/glass-cliff/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">glass cliff</a>” shows struggling companies are more likely to appoint women and people of color as CEO. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Other highlights</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The 500 companies in Fortune’s list <a href="https://twitter.com/MorningBrew/status/1262403370968547338?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">account for</a> two-thirds of the American economy and $14.2 trillion in revenue. The top 10: Walmart, Amazon, ExxonMobil, Apple, CVS, Berkshire Hathaway, UnitedHealth Group, McKesson, AT&T, and AmerisourceBergen. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The rankings are based on FY2019 revenue, which means no factoring in the C-word. But Fortune <a href="https://fortune.com/2020/05/14/fortune-500-ceo-survey-coronavirus-pandemic-predictions/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">surveyed</a> the CEOs in April to hear how they’re managing the pandemic:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>27% think workers will be back in offices by the end of 2020. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Most think it’ll take until Q1 2022 before economic activity returns to pre-pandemic levels. 27% said Q1 2023. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> “It feels obvious that the aggregate revenues of the Fortune 500 will decline in 2020, and the ramifications will be devastating,” per Fortune Data Sheet.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/18/disneys-head-streaming-will-become-tiktok-ceo?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Kevin Mayer Leaves Disney for More Viral Pastures
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="dance" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=377 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/kbzpSxgaYfsSvyqYwz/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="dance" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/kbzpSxgaYfsSvyqYwz/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, TikTok announced Kevin Mayer will become its <a href="https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/disney-kevin-mayer-ceo-tiktok-1234609918/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">next CEO</a>. His credentials include leading Disney’s streaming division and strong footwork to that one Drake song.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">This is a big get. </strong>As head of the division called “Direct-to-Consumer & International,” Mayer presided over the release of Disney+, the company’s big dive into streaming. So far, so good: Since its November launch, Disney+ has racked up nearly 55 million subscribers.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">His new company isn’t doing too shabby either. TikTok has been a quarantine darling—the perfect video platform for showcasing the insane things people will do when stuck at home for two months. In late April, TikTok topped 2 billion global downloads; in Q1, it had the <a href="https://sensortower.com/blog/tiktok-downloads-2-billion?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">best quarter</a> of any app ever, per Sensor Tower. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">It wouldn’t be a Disney story without a little palace intrigue. </strong>Mayer was considered a likely choice to succeed former CEO Bob Iger when he stepped down in February. Instead, head of parks Bob Chapek was tapped for the position. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With Disney <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/05/coronavirus-sinks-disney-q2-earnings?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hobbled</a> from the coronavirus, maybe the snub was a blessing in disguise for Mayer? </p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
PHARMA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/18/promising-results-modernas-experimental-vaccine-send-markets-flying?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Moderna Family
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In good news for people who were tired of trying to pronounce remdesivir, biotech company Moderna announced yesterday its experimental COVID-19 vaccine showed promising results.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Those results: </strong>An early stage human trial showed that the vaccine was able to <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/05/18/health/coronavirus-vaccine-moderna-early-results/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">produce antibodies in patients</a> that fight off the virus, a key signal that a vaccine is working. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Markets rejoiced</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As has been the case for much of the current economic crisis, positive news from the medical community was the Mentos to the market’s Diet Coke. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Stocks had their </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/17/stock-futures-up-after-powell-says-economy-could-recover-some-this-year.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">biggest day</a></span><span> since early April, and Moderna’s shares closed up 20%.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Words of caution: </strong>This was only Phase 1 of a typically three-phased trial. There are “lots of vaccines that look good out of Phase 1 that don’t turn out to be good products,” explains Daniel Salmon, a director at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we’re here: </strong>Let’s add one more difficult-to-pronounce drug to the story. Yesterday, President Trump announced he has been taking the <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/18/trump-says-he-takes-hydroxychloroquine-to-prevent-coronavirus-infection.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">anti-malarial hydroxychloroquine</a> for the last week, despite an FDA advisory stating that the drug has “not been shown to be safe and effective” in preventing the coronavirus. </p>

</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/18/us-oil-prices-rally-two-month-high?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">

<img alt="Trump twete" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMDAyL3RydW1wX3R3ZXRlLnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>@realDonaldTrump</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">You heard him. On Monday, oil futures <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/18/oil-outlook-vastly-different-than-when-it-plunged-into-negative-territory-a-month-ago.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">rallied</a> to a two-month high ahead of today’s June contract expirations.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Refresher:</strong> Oil futures = financial instruments that let investors buy “abstract oil.” When futures contracts expire, they get converted into IRL oil. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Nightmare flashbacks</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When May contracts expired in late April, prices for the U.S. oil benchmark <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/20/us-crude-prices-dip-0-ahead-may-contract-expirations?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">collapsed into negative territory</a>. Some feared June expirations would trigger a similar slide. Last Wednesday, the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission warned brokerages and exchange operators they might need to intervene.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Thankfully, they were wrong. Oil prices are trading above $30 for the first time since mid-March. Send thank you notes to...</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Rising demand for oil in reopening economies, especially the U.S. and China</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Supply cuts amounting to 10.7 million barrels/day </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s </span><span><a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/full-transcript-fed-chair-jerome-powell-60-minutes-interview-economic-recovery-from-coronavirus-pandemic/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pacifying economic commentary</a></span><span> on </span><span><em>60 Minutes </em></span><span>Sunday night </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> Prices are still only half of January’s high of $60+/barrel, it’s still the early days for reopenings, and the threat of a second COVID-19 outbreak casts a long shadow.</p>

VENTURE CAPITAL
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/18/softbanks-slidemaker-chief?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
SoftBank’s Slidemaker in Chief Is at it Again
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>

<img alt="PPT illustration " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8xMDAxL3BwdF9pbGx1c3RyYXRpb24uanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>SoftBank</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">SoftBank’s <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-18/softbank-s-first-vision-fund-may-be-last-after-18-billion-loss?sref=KkPzpZvz&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">earnings call</a> yesterday was the latest instance of CEO Masayoshi Son using the powers of Microsoft Paint to illustrate his grand vision.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>In 2010 Son was </span><span><a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/13-slides-softbanks-vision-for-next-300-years-2017-10#the-presentation-starts-by-highlighting-some-of-the-technologies-that-could-exist-within-30-years-before-moving-on-to-look-deep-into-the-future-4?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">game-planning for the next 300 years</a></span><span> with nuggets of copy like, “Think till our brains crush.” </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>You also have to check out his 2019 presentation outlining </span><span><a href="https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/qvg94x/these-delusional-powerpoint-slides-show-how-softbank-wants-to-save-wework?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">WeWork’s path to profitability</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This latest slide deck broke down the unicorn-gobbling effect of the “Valley of Coronavirus.”</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>SoftBank's $100 billion Vision Fund, which holds large stakes in WeWork and Uber, reported a $17.7 billion loss in the last fiscal year, the worst loss in the company's 39-year history.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> The performance of Vision Fund 1.0 has all but killed hopes of raising external financing for Vision Fund 2.0 “If the results are bad, you can’t raise money from investors,” Son explained.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ While we're here:</strong> SoftBank is reportedly <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/softbank-plans-to-seek-buyers-for-about-20-billion-of-its-t-mobile-shares-11589836379?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">looking to sell</a> $20 billion worth of shares in T-Mobile in what would be one of the biggest stock trades in history, the WSJ reports. </p>

collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Fortune 500 list is a bit like prom: Walmart’s been queen eight-years running, and you can \u003cem\u003epretty\u003c/em\u003e much guess who else is joining onstage. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut there’s another group worth keeping tabs on—companies with female CEOs, which last year \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/2020/05/18/women-ceos-fortune-500-2020/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejumped 12%\u003c/a\u003e to...37. That means just 7.4% of Fortune 500 companies have a female CEO. Of those...\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOnly three in the Global 500 are women of color (Gap’s Sonia Syngal, AMD’s Lisa Su, Yum China’s Joey Wat); none are black or Latina.  \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSeven lead a Fortune 100 company. More head smaller companies at the bottom of the rankings. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThings are improving...slowly\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut the lack of representation bleeds into other senior leadership positions, like board rooms.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAccording to Deloitte’s Women in the Boardroom, 18% of North American board seats in 2018 were \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://hbr.org/2020/02/gender-parity-in-the-boardroom-wont-happen-on-its-own?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eheld by women\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, while 4.5% of chairs were.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eLast year, California became the first state to set a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/17/us/california-boardroom-gender-quota.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eminimum requirement\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e for female board members at publicly held companies.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOne trend to watch:\u003c/strong\u003e Research into the “\u003ca href=\"https://freakonomics.com/podcast/glass-cliff/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eglass cliff\u003c/a\u003e” shows struggling companies are more likely to appoint women and people of color as CEO. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eOther highlights\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe 500 companies in Fortune’s list \u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/MorningBrew/status/1262403370968547338?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaccount for\u003c/a\u003e two-thirds of the American economy and $14.2 trillion in revenue. The top 10: Walmart, Amazon, ExxonMobil, Apple, CVS, Berkshire Hathaway, UnitedHealth Group, McKesson, AT\u0026T, and AmerisourceBergen. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe rankings are based on FY2019 revenue, which means no factoring in the C-word. But Fortune \u003ca href=\"https://fortune.com/2020/05/14/fortune-500-ceo-survey-coronavirus-pandemic-predictions/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esurveyed\u003c/a\u003e the CEOs in April to hear how they’re managing the pandemic:\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003e27% think workers will be back in offices by the end of 2020. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMost think it’ll take until Q1 2022 before economic activity returns to pre-pandemic levels. 27% said Q1 2023. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e “It feels obvious that the aggregate revenues of the Fortune 500 will decline in 2020, and the ramifications will be devastating,” per Fortune style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, TikTok announced Kevin Mayer will become its \u003ca href=\"https://variety.com/2020/digital/news/disney-kevin-mayer-ceo-tiktok-1234609918/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enext CEO\u003c/a\u003e. His credentials include leading Disney’s streaming division and strong footwork to that one Drake song.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThis is a big get. \u003c/strong\u003eAs head of the division called “Direct-to-Consumer \u0026 International,” Mayer presided over the release of Disney+, the company’s big dive into streaming. So far, so good: Since its November launch, Disney+ has racked up nearly 55 million subscribers.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHis new company isn’t doing too shabby either. TikTok has been a quarantine darling—the perfect video platform for showcasing the insane things people will do when stuck at home for two months. In late April, TikTok topped 2 billion global downloads; in Q1, it had the \u003ca href=\"https://sensortower.com/blog/tiktok-downloads-2-billion?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ebest quarter\u003c/a\u003e of any app ever, per Sensor Tower. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIt wouldn’t be a Disney story without a little palace intrigue. \u003c/strong\u003eMayer was considered a likely choice to succeed former CEO Bob Iger when he stepped down in February. Instead, head of parks Bob Chapek was tapped for the position. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith Disney \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/05/coronavirus-sinks-disney-q2-earnings?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehobbled\u003c/a\u003e from the coronavirus, maybe the snub was a blessing in disguise for Mayer? \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS Some feared June expirations would trigger a similar slide. Last Wednesday, the U.S. Commodity Futures Trading Commission warned brokerages and exchange operators they might need to intervene.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThankfully, they were wrong. Oil prices are trading above $30 for the first time since mid-March.
